results.headline: Checking In and Not Checking Out
results.summary_short: This banal horror retread involves a couple of critters flailing inside a sticky trap for what is, in effect, the big-screen equivalent of a roach motel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vacancy

results.headline: Misadventures of a Paper Boy
results.summary_short: “A Dios Momo,” directed by Leonardo Ricagni, is to melodrama as corn syrup is to sweeteners: efficient but crude.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye Momo

results.headline: Fallen Angels With Fuzzy Halos
results.summary_short: “Downtown: A Street Tale” is a hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it’s performing Tennessee Williams.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Downtown: A Street Tale

results.headline: Casualties of China’s Transformed Economy
results.summary_short: “Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks” is an astonishingly intimate record of China’s painful transition from state-run industry to a free market.
results.display_title: Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tie Xi Qu: West of Tracks

results.headline: Modern Life, in All Its Mystery and Madness
results.summary_short: Alejandro Jodorowsky’s  “Holy Mountain” is a dazzling, rambling, often incoherent satire on consumerism, militarism and exploitation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Holy Mountain

results.headline: Kiss Kiss, Vroom Vroom: They Were Born to Drive
results.summary_short: The movie “Redline” is all about surfaces, for young men with testosterone to burn.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redline

results.headline: Nose With an Imagination, and Hard-Boiled Crime
results.summary_short: “Slow Burn” is a wooden police thriller that is as dull as it is impenetrable and ultimately beyond ludicrous.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slow Burn

results.headline: Paris Believes in Tears (and Love and Real Estate)
results.summary_short: Things happen in “Private Fears in Public Places,” much as they do in life. But because this is an Alain Resnais film, things happen in near-geometric alignment.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Private Fears In Public Places

results.headline: In a Lonely Place, Saved by Puppies
results.summary_short: “Year of the Dog” is funny ha-ha but firmly in touch with its downer side, which means it’s also funny in a kind of existential way.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Year of the Dog

results.headline: Surveillance and Subterfuge in Corporate Shadows
results.summary_short: Even after it lurches from the far-fetched into the preposterous, “Perfect Stranger” leaves a clammy residue of unease.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Perfect Stranger

results.headline: Cops Trail Creeps on the Lam
results.summary_short: “Lonely Hearts”  succeeds better than many crime dramas in balancing the philosophical with the visceral.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lonely Hearts

results.headline: From Call Girl to Kant Girl in a Flash of White Panties
results.summary_short: The overripe morsel who gets batted around in the Japanese absurdithon “The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai” looks like she was conjured up by a teenage boy in dangerous hormonal overdrive.
results.display_title: The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Glamorous Life of Sachiko Hanai

results.headline: A Dissection of an Abduction
results.summary_short: With “Voice of a Murderer,” the unpredictable Korean director Park Jin-pyo returns to the docudrama form.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Voice of a Murderer

results.headline: Norsemen of the Apocalypse
results.summary_short: All grunting, all goring, the witless action flick “Pathfinder” has little to recommend it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pathfinder

results.headline: Minimalism in Motion
results.summary_short: “Modern Man,” the debut feature from Justin Swibel, may leave you seeing the world with fresh eyes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Modern Man

results.headline: A New Life, by Chance
results.summary_short: Paulo Costanzo and Steph Song make a sweet screen couple in “Everything’s Gone Green,” but Vancouver is the real star of the movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Everything's Gone Green

results.headline: Meaty Comedy
results.summary_short: The point of “Aqua Teen Hunger Force” is not “South Park”-style topical satire, but rather endless riffing on pop culture minutiae.
results.display_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters

results.headline: Inside Story of a Hip-Hop Return to Glory
results.summary_short: The lively hip-hop documentary “Rock the Bells” demands neither familiarity with the music nor a hankering for rhyme.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rock the Bells

results.headline: An Artist’s Underground Flowering
results.summary_short: It’s gratifying when an influential underground artist is profiled in an accessible  documentary.  For that reason alone, “Jack Smith and the Destruction of Atlantis” is worth seeing.
results.display_title: Jack Smith & the Destruction of Atlantis

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Smith & the Destruction of Atlantis

results.headline: True Story of a Fake Story About Hughes (Really)
results.summary_short: The literary and journalistic frauds of the present era are small potatoes compared to the work of Clifford Irving, the subject of “The Hoax.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hoax
